def_cn: （用于广场或较短街道的名称中）广场，街
def_en: Place is used as part of the name of a square or short street in a town.
A place is any point, building, area, town, or country.

def_cn: （已提到过的）地方,地点，地区
def_en: You can use the place to refer to the point, building, area, town, or country that you have already mentioned.
You can refer to somewhere that provides a service, such as a hotel, restaurant, or institution, as a particular kind of place.

def_cn: （尤指在控制或组织下）发生，进行，举行
def_en: When something takes place, it happens, especially in a controlled or organized way.

def_cn: （用于 any，no，some 或 every 之后）…地方
def_en: Place can be used after 'any', 'no', 'some', or 'every' to mean 'anywhere', 'nowhere', 'somewhere', or 'everywhere'.
If you go places, you visit pleasant or interesting places.

def_cn: 所属的位置；应在的位置；适当的位置
def_en: You can refer to the position where something belongs, or where it is supposed to be, as its place .
A place is a seat or position that is available for someone to occupy.
Someone's or something's place in a society, system, or situation is their position in relation to other people or things.

def_cn: （比赛或竞赛获得的）名次
def_en: Your place in a race or competition is your position in relation to the other competitors. If you are in first place, you are ahead of all the other competitors.
If you get a place in a team, on a committee, or on a course of study, for example, you are accepted as a member of the team or committee or as a student on the course.
A good place to do something in a situation or activity is a good time or stage at which to do it.
Your place is the house or flat where you live.

def_cn: （书等中）正读到的部分；（演说等中）正讲到的地方
def_en: Your place in a book or speech is the point you have reached in reading the book or making the speech.
If you say how many decimal places there are in a number, you are saying how many numbers there are to the right of the decimal point.

def_cn: （尤指小心、稳当或特意地）放置
def_en: If you place something somewhere, you put it in a particular position, especially in a careful, firm, or deliberate way.
To place a person or thing in a particular state means to cause them to be in it.

def_cn: 把（重点等）放（在）；将（责任等）归（于）
def_en: You can use place instead of 'put' or 'lay' in certain expressions where the meaning is carried by the following noun. For example, if you place emphasis on something, you emphasize it, and if you place the blame on someone, you blame them.

def_cn: 评定，划分（为某一等级或类别）
def_en: If you place someone or something in a particular class or group, you label or judge them in that way.

def_cn: （在比赛或竞赛中）使获得第…名，使名列；（美国英语中常指）使获得亚军，使名列第二
def_en: If a competitor is placed first, second, or last, for example, that is their position at the end of a race or competition. In American English, be placed often means 'finish in second position'.
If you place an order for a product or for a meal, you ask for it to be sent or brought to you.
If you place an advertisement in a newspaper, you arrange for the advertisement to appear in the newspaper.

def_cn: （请接线员帮助接通时）说出，给出（联系人的电话号码）
def_en: If you place a telephone call to a particular place, you give the telephone operator the number of the person you want to speak to and ask them to connect you.
If you place a bet, you bet money on something.

def_cn: 为…找到职位；安插；为…找到住处；安置
def_en: If an agency or organization places someone, it finds them a job or somewhere to live.
If you say that you cannot place someone, you mean that you recognize them but cannot remember exactly who they are or where you have met them before.
meeting place;
If something is happening all over the place, it is happening in many different places.

def_cn: （通常指乱七八糟地）随处遍布
def_en: If things are all over the place, they are spread over a very large area, usually in a disorganized way.
If you say that someone is all over the place, you mean that they are confused or disorganized, and unable to think clearly or act properly.
If you change places with another person, you start being in their situation or role, and they start being in yours.

If you have been trying to understand something puzzling and then everything falls into place or clicks into place, you suddenly understand how different pieces of information are connected and everything becomes clearer.

def_cn: （事件等）自然而然地按所希望的方式发生
def_en: If things fall into place, events happen naturally to produce a situation you want.

def_cn: （很可能）获得成功，飞黄腾达
def_en: If you say that someone is going places, you mean that they are showing a lot of talent or ability and are likely to become very successful.

def_cn: （在政府、社会或组织中）身居高位
def_en: People in high places are people who have powerful and influential positions in a government, society, or organization.

def_cn: 在/不在正确的位置；在/不在通常的位置
def_en: If something is in place, it is in its correct or usual position. If it is out of place, it is not in its correct or usual position.

def_cn: （法律、政策、行政体系等）正在运作，就位
def_en: If something such as a law, a policy, or an administrative structure is in place, it is working or able to be used.
If one thing or person is used or does something in place of another, they replace the other thing or person.
If something has particular characteristics or features in places, it has them at several points within an area.

def_cn: 身在…的处境；处于…的位置
def_en: If you say what you would have done in someone else's place, you say what you would have done if you had been in their situation and had been experiencing what they were experiencing.
You say in the first place when you are talking about the beginning of a situation or about the situation as it was before a series of events.

def_cn: （用于列举事项）第一/第二，首先/其次；（用于强调）首要的是
def_en: You say in the first place and in the second place to introduce the first and second in a series of points or reasons. In the first place can also be used to emphasize a very important point or reason.

def_cn: （做…）不正确，不妥当，不在职责范围内
def_en: If you say that it is not your place to do something, you mean that it is not right or appropriate for you to do it, or that it is not your responsibility to do it.

def_cn: 格格不入；不相称；不适当；不适时
def_en: If someone or something seems out of place in a particular situation, they do not seem to belong there or to be suitable for that situation.

def_cn: 有利的境遇；一帆风顺的位置
def_en: If you say that someone has found their place in the sun, you mean that they are in a job or a situation where they will be happy and have everything that they want.
If you place one thing above ,before, or over another, you think that the first thing is more important than the second and you show this in your behaviour.
If you put someone in their place, you show them that they are less important or clever than they think they are.

def_cn: （常为幽默用法）使有自知之明，使识相
def_en: If you say that someone should be shown their place or be kept in their place, you are saying, often in a humorous way, that they should be made aware of their low status.
If one thing takes second place to another, it is considered to be less important and is given less attention than the other thing.
If one thing or person takes the place of another or takes another's place, they replace the other thing or person.
pride of place→see: pride;
